docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You have no problem with doctors' organizing to improve the lives of patients, but you conjure up horrible images if doctors are allowed to organize to improve their own lives (editorial, April 8). This is based on your false premise that what is good for doctors is bad for patients. In fact, the opposite is true. Consider these two medical practices. In practice A we have a relaxed doctor, running his practice at a comfortable pace because he knows that at the end of the day he will have both appreciation and a reasonable income. In practice B we have an angry, harried doctor, running from one exam room to another every 12 minutes because he knows that if he slowed down, he might not make his payroll.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE pharmaceutical industry has a lot of problems in Washington these days, its prices and profits proving an irresistible target for politicians with hard-pressed elderly constituents and an election on the horizon. But there are few more persistent irritants than Representative Bernard Sanders, the democratic socialist from Vermont who is one of two independents in the House. Mr. Sanders, a gruff-spoken 58-year-old native of Flatbush, with a thatch of white hair and a rumpled 60's-academic style, has twice taken elderly constituents on well-publicized trips to Canada to buy prescription drugs, highlighting the lower prices across the border.

headline.main: Independent No Longer Alone in Fight Over Drug Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: Shots explode at a school in Oregon, a brokerage office in Atlanta, or a church in Fort Worth, and the nation is witness to another sudden, seemingly random violent rampage. Before the ambulances leave, the news crews arrive. The killers' neighbors, friends or families submit to interviews, and inevitably, they say something like this: ''He just snapped.'' But the killers do not just snap. An examination by The New York Times of 100 rampage murders found that most of the killers spiraled down a long slow slide, mentally and emotionally. Most of them left a road map of red flags, spending months plotting their attacks and accumulating weapons, talking openly of their plans for bloodshed. Many showed signs of serious mental health problems.

headline.main: The Well-Marked Roads to Homicidal Rage

docs.abstract: Second of four articles in series, Rampage Killers, explores how relatives, colleagues and officials frequently overlook warning signs that precede most rampage killings; examination of 100 rampage murders disputes notion that killers just 'snap'; finds most of killers spiraled down long slow slide, mentally and emotionally; most of them spent months plotting their attacks and accumulating weapons, talking openly of their plans for bloodshed; in cases where families or friends tried to find help, they were rebuffed by police, school administrators or mental health workers; this suggests that many rampage killings could be prevented if people understood more about mental illness and connected clues; detailed description of several rampage killers: Jamie Rouse, who killed teachers and students at his Giles County, Tenn, high school; Sylvia Segrist, who opened fire at Philadelphia shopping mall, killing three people and injuring seven; Jeffrey Wade Wallace, who killed one person and injured three others at Key West, Fla, bar where he once worked; Joseph Brooks Jr, who killed his psychiatrist and several members of his therapy group in Southland, Mich, then killed himself; James Flood Davis, who killed bosses who had fired him, as well as co-workers at warehouse in Asheville, NC; Kip Kinkel, 15, who killed his parents, then went to his school in Springfield, Ore, and shot 24 people, killing two students; Sgt William Kreutzer Jr, who opened fire on fellow soldiers at Fort Bragg, NC, wounding 18 of them and killing one officer; photos; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to government, city folks have always felt inferior to suburbanites. Rudy Giuliani notwithstanding, New Yorkers believe that theirs is a land of big-spending pols and inefficient public services. They also take it on faith that the suburbs have small, cost-conscious work forces monitored by diligent chief executives who came up through the ranks of the League of Women Voters. It's all a fable. The real suburbs are usually a governmental mess -- overlapping fiefs with layers of ancient taxing districts and triple-tier services. Virtually crime-free hamlets are guarded by state, county and municipal cops. Dueling town and county plows are deployed every time an inch of snow falls. Fast-growing townships spend hundreds of millions of dollars a year under the leadership of a part-time chief executive and a couple of clerks with pocket calculators.

headline.main: Blundering In The Burbs; That Sleek Suburban Political Machine

docs.abstract: Gail Collins article describes how Nassau County, NY, managed to go broke during longest economic boom in American history; argues that when it comes to bad government, nothing beats Nassau County, one of oldest suburban enclaves in nation, home to 1.3 million residents, many of whose parents fled across Queens border after World War II to escape city life; observes that on resources-to-results basis, Nassau County, with more per capita wealth than Palm Beach County and a virtually nonexistent unemployment rate, is possibly the worst-run political institution in country; notes that Nassau, like many suburbs that is less efficient than they might be, is such a hodgepodge of different governmental entities that the most diligent citizen would need flow chart to figure it out; holds county's books are a mess, and its credit rating is one level away from junk-bond status; reports Nassau has highest sales tax rate in nation and its taxes on commercial property are higher than New York City's, but nevertheless its debt is $2.5 billion and rising; holds Nassau has failed to develop institutional skill in labor negotiation; says most of its services are good, but at very high labor cost; holds one-party rule has led Nassau into its present fix, noting that county has been controlled for virtually all of its 100-year history by Republican machine; argues that one-party rule almost invariably leads to waste and corruption; notes that in November, fed-up voters in Nassau rebelled and elected County Legislature with on-evote Democratic majority under Judy Jacobs leadership; notes that majority disappeared in March when one of Demoratic legislators died; a special election in May will decide which party will control legislature; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Driving a car in New Jersey under the best conditions (itself a contradiction), requires constant vigilance and unlimited patience. ''Talking and Driving: Growing Road Menace?'' (Cover March 26), will, I hope, result in a call for responsible action on the part of our legislators. While no law can ever bring back loved ones killed as a result of inattention by a driver using a cell phone it is amazing that we do not demand more of our elected officials or for that matter ourselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a 15-minute office visit in February 1999, a cardiologist told the parents of Dominic Fernandez, 3, that he needed open heart surgery and a possible heart transplant -- ''right now, or he will not survive through the summer.'' ''We were just overwhelmed,'' said Beverly Fernandez, a warehouse manager for Honeywell. Her son was still recovering from surgery nine months earlier for congenital heart problems. ''I wanted to know more about transplants'' and the alternatives, she said.
